comments.commentBody: The position that my one vote doesn't count makes no sense.  How do you think a candidate gets millions of votes if not one vote at a time.  This is one election where you will live with some very consequential outcomes so throwing a vote at an individual with no chance to win has a very high potential for getting you something worse than a candidate you simply don't like.

If in a tight race, every party matters, then the NYTimes should be advocating that both Jill Stein and Gary Johnson be allowed on the debate stage with Mr. Trump and Hillary. In that way, a wide audience can in my view realize Jill Stein advocates for sensible views that merit support: A Green New Deal. If the NYTimes is so confident about its views, then logically the American people would be able to figure out who meritless these 3rd party candidates are.

I think the NYTimes editorial board has not fairly represented Dr Stein’s views. I would call it to borrow a phrase from Hillary – “Artful Smear. “

I cannot wait until election day to vote for Jill Stein. It will be the most meaningful vote this 50+ person has ever cast. Why? America's 40+ year drift to the corporate right is not going to work for this country or the people of this planet. The Democratic Party is no longer the party of progressive values, but rather Republican light. The only way I can impact our country with my vote is to clearly signal the Democratic Party cannot continue to drift right, but return to progressive values of FDR – a Green New Deal.

I'm sick of our increasingly polarized, dysfunctional, money-driven politics and long for a fresh approach, and I took a careful look at the Libertarian website to see what that party proposes.  It seems like they just want to go back to the 19th century.  That might be good fun in adventure films, but the average life expectancy was around 39 years.  Anyone who thinks it would be a good idea to "replace harmful government agencies like the Food & Drug Administration (FDA) with more agile, free-market alternatives," please look up Upton Sinclair, the Radium Girls, and Thalidomide.

My own order of preference is:

1) Sanders

2) Jill Stein

3) Trump

4) Gary Johnson

5) Clinton

Sanders is out - thanks to you Democrats.

Are you suggesting that I NOT vote for Jill Stein? Trump would be the next choice.

In a choice between vulgarity and obscenity, I may have to live with one or the other of the dishonorable churls nominated by the major parties.  I may have to live with it.  But I don't have to vote for it.  Don't settle for the lesser of two evils.  Vote for Gary Johnson or Jill Stein for the greater good.

Wow, a vote not for Clinton is a vote for xenophobia, intolerance, and ignorance? That'll win some third-party voters for Clinton.

I respectfully disagree that Clinton needs to win big. Clinton and the DNC cannot afford to relax. We cannot afford Clinton and the DNC assuming they have a mandate for Democratic politics as usual and ignoring the factors that fueled the candidacies of Sanders and, I hate to even put him in the same paragraph, Trump.

By all means, if you're in a swing state, vote Blue down the ticket.

In fact, either Clinton or Trump will be President. If you feel it makes a difference who the next President will be you should vote for one or the other.  Enough people in Florida in 2000 felt there was no difference between GWB and Gore and voted for Ralph Nader. Hundreds of thousands of people died in Iraq because Bush was President and the Middle East is still a mess.  Voting has real consequences --- and they can be catastrophic.  I think Trump would be a catastrophe as President and will vote for Clinton.  As a former supporter of Bernie Sanders, I will support him in his efforts to ensure that real change takes place after Clinton is elected.

I have worked in four elections which were decided by less than 50 votes. One was decided by four votes. Yes, your vote counts.

What your vote means in election as a whole is complex. If you truly don't want to see one candidate elected, you should vote for the candidate most likely to defeat him. It's math.

"These proposals are so off-the-charts unaffordable that they would never pass any Congress, regardless of which political party held a majority." Dr. Stein's proposals are not unaffordable if this country's government stops pouring trillions into foreign adventurism, fairly tax Wall Street bankers and multi-national corporations and instead starts addressing the needs of our citizens at Home. This country needs to forgive student debt. make public higher education free and provide universal single payer health care.

I suggest that Green Party supporter ignore the NY Times editorial board stick to their guns and vote for the Dr. Jill Stein for President on November 8th. I also suggest that Bernie Sanders Supporter do the same.

Even in non-tight races third parties matter: they bring forth directions, values, and visions that are not reflected in the two establishment parties. If the latter are so sure of their hold on social, ecological and political truth why should their Commission not include third parties that have managed to get registered (with great effort) in 50 states?

Since I founded the first Green local in New York State by starting the Queens Green Party in 1989, I continue to believe that the Green movement shows the right values and vision for a sustainable future. Included is its programs is the issue of money creation and public financing and Stein is right of spending directly into the economy without the intermediary of privately owned banking systems the trillion dollars that is owned by students. They would spend these funds, unlike banks which are not geared towards the public good.

Having been an environmentalist for many decades I would like the Green movement go beyond money creation issue and stimulate a broad discussion about transforming the unjust, unsustainable and, therefore, unstable international monetary system by basing it on the monetary standard of a specific tonnage of CO2e per person. The conceptual, institutional, ethical and strategic dimensions of such carbon-based international monetary system are presented in Verhagen 2012 "The Tierra Solution: Resolving the climate crisis through monetary transformation" and updated in www.timun.net.

The Green party platform is entirely unrealistic both economically and politically, and needs to mature significantly to be taken seriously.

The Libertarian party platform is naivete disguised as high level economics. The belief that less regulation, less tax revenue, and a diminished federal government will lead to better outcomes for the bulk of the American populace (poor and middle class) runs exactly counter to history. It has some valuable ideas, but too many alarming ones.

After watching the debate last night, I am glad that it was only Trump and Clinton on that stage. Deciding between those two candidates is the reality of this election, and observing them head to head as much as possible (without devoting time to fringe candidates) is to the benefit of the American people.

If the Green Party and the Libertarian Party want to be taken seriously on the national stage, they need to actually build political machinery and not just appear opportunistically every 4 years.

Jill Stein and Gary Johnson represent two very different extremes in two different dimensions than we usually are treated to by our major parties. I would like to see more than two parties, but those two are off the radar in their extreme positions.

The odd thing is that I like certain aspects of libertarianism and am very much an environmentalist. But, free university for all and no income or inheritance taxes are both crazy ideas. Even Europe doesn't do either. Their free higher education is not for all and flies in the face of libertarian ideals.

No matter how much I might respect Jill Stein as an individual of strong character and for her work as an activist or how much I might agree with her positions on many ,if not all,  issues, I think it would be totally irresponsible to vote for her.  What concerns me about her candidacy, even if Trump were not in the race, is her glaring lack of relevant experience for the position and her naive and troubling  assumption that she is qualified to lead this country in the current domestic and international turmoil.   Serving on a town council for two terms is not adequate preparation for the complex and varied demands of the presidency of the supposedly most powerful country in the world.   Experience as an activist or as a protester is not proof of an ability to govern.  I also find her bid to draw a protest vote unlikely to bring about the changes she hopes to see and, in this particular election, dangerously irresponsible.  She won't be President and she shouldn't be.  If she truly had the best interests of the nation at heart, she would recognize the potential consequences of her Nader -like bid and withdraw.  We of the older generation saw the disastrous results of Nader's candidacy.  Surely, she could and should direct her abilities and convictions toward more realistic and more productive ways to effect change.

Were the real candidates the buffoon and the buffooness that were on stage last night? The people have spoken and these are what we get? I was going to vote for Trump because I didn't want to waste my vote, but I can't vote for either of these unqualified candidates. I'll waste my vote on Johnson. Good luck everybody.

So on the same day the NY Times is informing its readers about a WHO report on air pollution (9 out of 10 people in the world are breathing "bad air" according to the report) it's telling readers not to vote for the only party that takes climate change seriously. This disconnect is confusing and, honestly, disappointing.

So I am a white, 66 year old building contractor who still works day-to-day with my crew in a small town in northwest Washington State....my question is what kind of America do I want my 4 yr. old granddaughter to grow up in?  She is a child of our world - Korean, Danish, Filipino, German, Mexican, Irish - and like all of us, a descendent of those long ago East Africans.  Born American will she be welcomed in Trump's bigoted America? Or will she be allowed to thrive in pay-for-play Clinton's? ........I am looking elsewhere and I am seriously looking at Gary Johnson.  He should be in the debates and the Times should have endorsed his inclusion.
Its better to vote for 85% of what you want and get it, than vote for 95% of what you want and not get it.

To the Editor:
I was thoroughly unpersuaded by your editorial discouraging voters from supporting third party candidates, and for the first time in my life am contemplating a vote Libertarian Party, based on three simple facts.
1. Donald Trump is temptrementally unsuited to be president.
2. Hillary Clinton's flagrant dishonesty renders her unsuitable for the job.
3. New York’s overwhelming support for Democrats ensures that all of its Electoral votes will go to Hillary, regardless of how I vote.

Accordingly, the most effective way for me to express my dissatisfaction with the status quo and the incompetents that the major parties have offered up, is to vote Libertarian. Even a moderately better-than-expected showing for this party will send an unmistakable message to the political powers that be.

Since surveys suggest that my dissatisfaction is widely shared, I would challenge the NY Times to offer a better way to express these views.

You've convinced me not to vote Trump. I have no desire to vote Clinton. I don't care that it might cause someone who shouldn't get into office to get into office. In my mind, either person who wins shouldn't get into office. Work to convince Millennials like myself that we want Clinton.

Don't tell us we're idiots if you want to convince us, tell us what you are planning on doing to make our lives better.

Explain how hiring the person directly responsible for tipping the scales against us once she stepped down was not a corrupt move. Release speeches made to Wall Street executives. Explain how you'd prosecute said executives.

Or don't. Don't blame me. Blame yourselves.
Since you asked, Len, None of the Above would be the best possible outcome in a two stinker election.
Last night’s debate probably did more to help Johnson and Stein than it did to help Trump and Clinton.
